dialogues.text: July 1966. Fog. Dense. Unhealthy. British. A tired-looking road sign reads ‘Barnes Common’. The fog clears a little to reveal: a police telephone box. Old. Battered. And, as we fade from black and white to colour... Blue. A sign on one door panel reads: ‘Officers and cars respon urgent calls’. Traffic goes carefully past. Caption: 1966. One car trundles to a halt and just stays there, headligh carving yellow tunnels into the fog. The door of the Police Box opens, throwing a shaft of lig into the night, and a policeman, REG, appears. He looks o towards the road and sees the stationary car, its engine ticking over. He frowns, clicks on a powerful torch and w down to the road.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting at the wheel of the car, staring into space, is a grey-faced man, much older-looking than his 58 years. Wil Hartnell - BILL to his friends. At the moment, he doesn’t have many of those. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 There’s a knock at the window. Bill doesn’t seem to hear. REG, the policeman, tries again.

dialogues.speaker: REG
dialogues.text: Everything alright, sir? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: REG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you ok? Bill seems lost in reverie.

dialogues.speaker: REG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need to move along now, sir. Bill turns to him. He looks haunted. REG (CONT’D) Sir, you're in the way. Bill winds down the window.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Eh? Reg turns the torch on him.

dialogues.speaker: REG
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir but you... ‘Ere! Aren't you - ?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (snaps out of it) Sorry. Very sorry, officer. Rapidly he winds up the window, puts the car into gear --

dialogues.speaker: REG
dialogues.text: You're him, aren’t you! You’re Doctor Who! -- and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: REG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait till I tell the kids! They bloomin’ love you! Reg smiles as he watches the car vanish into the fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL motors along, but he seems miles away. Tears well in eyes. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL

dialogues.speaker: A CYBERMAN
dialogues.text: It has blank sockets instead of eyes and its face is made a stretchy cloth like a stocking mask. Instead of ears it huge, handle-like projections. It raises a recognisably human hand, puffs on a skinny woodbine, then flops down into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Len! For God’s sake! The Cyberman (LEN) swings round. DOUGLAS CAMFIELD, the st A.D. stalks furiously up to him. DOUGLAS (CONT’D) You'll go up like a Roman Candle if you're not careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: No. We'll be starting up again ina minute.

dialogues.speaker: LEN, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: 19:16 ECU the back of Bill’s head. The flowing white hair...

dialogues.text: The incredible original. It’s brightly lit, though the wa are, unexpectedly, a pale peppermint green, not white. At centre, the big hexagonal control console, covered in dia and gauges and switches. The glass cylinder in the middle still and silent. Lying under the console is a sweaty and grumpy young STAGE HAND. He tries to force the glass cylinder to move but it’s stu fast so he gets up and walks off, not noticing BILL, stan in the doorway. dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March 1963 Music: ‘Dansevise’ by Grethe and Jorgen Inmann. Driving a swanky, slightly vulgar sports car is a swanky, slightly vulgar man. He has a distinctive toothbrush moustache and a cigarette holder clamped between his teet This is SYDNEY. The car streaks into TV Centre car park. HERO c/u of Sydney against the ‘doughnut’, getting out of car. Like the titles of a 60s spy TV show. HARRY, a uniformed security guard, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Can I see your pass, sir?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Come on, Harry. You know my face...

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: That's as maybe, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Sydney Newman. Clue’s in the name. (points at himself) Better than any mug-shot.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: Still need to see your pass, sir. With a heavy sigh, Sydney marches past Harry.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s not the way we do things at the BBC, sir!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You don’t say.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYDNEY marches purposefully along a corridor. Beat. He comes back the way he came. Lost. Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is ajar. On it a sign: Sydney Newman - Head of Drama. Reading a report, SYDNEY sits opposite two men - the shar faced REX TUCKER, and a quiet, pipe-smoking man in spectacles, MERVYN PINFIELD.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: So, we got a great big thumping audience for ‘Grandstand’ but we lose them before the teeny boppers tune in for ‘Juke Box Jury’, right?

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Right. Erm... correct.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: We got a gap to plug.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: Twenty five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: How about another Dickens? Sydney pulls a face.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Fossilised, Mervyn! Fusty. Frowsty. And lots of less polite words beginning with ‘F’. Here’s a word for you, though: Fun! FUN! You heard of fun, Mervyn?

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: (drily) It that something else you've brought from ITV?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I hope so. We need stuff to keep the sports fans hooked and the kids too. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Competitive Tiddly-winks?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You know what I’m talking about.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: (sighs) Science-fiction? Is it that popular?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: It was last time I took a look.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: With juvenile boys, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (a steely smile) I like it.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.text: Early June 1963 A nice London mews flat. The sound of a hip party in full swing.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a blur of beehives, skinny trousers, ciggies and jaz In the corner is a glum-looking heavily PREGNANT GIRL, smoking. A striking, dark-haired young woman, VERITY (LAMBERT) is dancing with JACKIE (JACQUELINE HILL), equal striking, with her hair piled up. She glances over at the pregnant girl and throws a surprised look back at Verity. They yell over the noise of the party.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: She thought the balloon had gone up.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: She thought we’d all had it. Cuba! No point in holding back if the missiles started flying. So she put it about a bit. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: A lot! The music stops and they sink down exhaustedly onto the c covered sofa. They both have large glasses of red wine.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what did they say?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: “You're only a production assistant, dear. It’s a bit of a leap”. (sighs) I'm giving myself a year, Jackie. Get on in TV - or get out.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Listen. What do I know? I spend my time trying not to bump into the cameras - but don’t pack in yet, Verity. Softly, softly, eh? Verity shrugs and drinks her wine. It leaves her with a r stain at the corners of her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointing at Verity's lips) You've got a —

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Oh. She takes out a hankie and rubs at the corners of her mou then panics.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh Lord, it’s on, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: The Space shot! The Soviets. Valentina whatsit. First woman in Space!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Oh God, yes! Verity dashes over to the tiny TV and switches it on. As valves warm up a picture appears. It’s the BBC’s terrible soap ‘Compact’. Verity twists a clunky switch and changes channel. A beaming female Cosmonaut appears, arriving bac Earth.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYDNEY gazes out over his new empire. He smokes. Thinks.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (sotto, to himself) Pop, pop, pop.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 10B INT. VERITY’S FLAT. NIGHT 2 - (19.24) 10B VERITY and JACKIE are on the sofa, watching the Cosmonaut fascinated. The phone starts ringing.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: I wonder if they’ve got any jobs going.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: The Russians. She reaches over for the phone, holding one hand over her against the din of the party.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? What? (listens) Oh! Sydney! Hello stranger.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (into phone) You know anything about children, Verity?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.text: (laughs ) Not a thing.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: June 1963 - a few days later. Double doors fly open and SYDNEY powers into BBC receptio VERITY in his wake. She wears a ‘GUEST ‘pass.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: We wanna do a science-fiction serial. Legitimate stuff, though. No tin robots or B.E.M.s

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: B.E.M.s?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Bug-Eyed Monsters! You know... Death rays and mutations. Brains in glass jars! All that kind of crap. Sydney tries to hand her a file. She doesn’t take it.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Give me the bare bones. They go through the doors into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the exterior of the ‘doughnut’.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: A good-looking guy, a good-looking girl and a kid who gets into trouble. Plus an older man. Quirky. I'll come back to him. They travel about in space and time getting into scrapes!

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Ooh! Lovely idea!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You know me. (mimes machine gun) Pop! Pop! Pop!

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 15
dialogues.text: Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they’re in the scene dock. It’s overflowing with Roma columns, fake shrubbery, painted flats.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: And we want history too. (gestures at flats) Proper history. The kids at home should learn something.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: And what about this other man? The quirky character?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: He’s a Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: He should be a doctor, don’t you think? Makes him an authority figure but still kinda reassuring. (reads from file) “He hates scientists. Inventors. Improvers. And his ultimate aim is to destroy the future!” Verity looks appalled. Ping! The lift doors open and they stride out.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Nuts!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: It’s nuts! It’s crazy! He sounds like a reactionary. Shouldn’t he be curious about the Universe? Excited by everything? We want him to have mad adventures, find things out, not stop progress!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYDNEY marches into his office, VERITY behind him.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Top marks! (laughs ) That’s junked! I’ve got a much better idea. He perches on the edge of his desk and tosses the file in her lap. On the cover, in biro is written ‘Dr Who’.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: (sighs) I'd love to work with you again, Sydney. Really I would. But... Look, I gave myself a year. Get on or - Sydney laughs and draws expansively on his cigarette. He looks every inch the old-fashioned Hollywood mogul.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to be my assistant again, kid! I want you to produce it!

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: (stunned) Produce it?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Sure. There’s never been a female producer here! You’re just what this place needs. Someone with piss and vinegar in their veins!

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think. Sydney draws on his cigarette again.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I did a show called ‘Pathfinders’ at ITV. You see it? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 18aA

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Um...

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: We had an old guy as the hero. A grumpy old guy. That’s what we want here.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ten-hut! You ‘orrible lot. I’ve never seen such a shower in all my born days!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The theme tune for ‘The Army Game’ belts out. BILL is against a wall, dressed as a Sergeant-Major, flan by two SQUADDIES.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (on screen) Wait for it, wait for it! Left turn! Oh my stars! What did I do to deserve you lot? This unit’s got as much future as a ruddy snowman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Drivel. Bill and his wife HEATHER are watching TV in the front ro of their cottage. Heather is sitting on the carpet, playi with their five year old granddaughter - JUDITH. A dog snuffles about. Bill is fixing himself a whisky.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No-one rung?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Not since you last asked.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Alright. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Five minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (sharp) Alright, alright!

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: I hate it when you’re like this. You've only been out of work a few weeks -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not built for lazing around, am I? I’ve got to graft. Or I'll go round the twist.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: What about that play - ?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Another ruddy army part! No fear. That’s all they ever offer me. Crooks and perishing Sergeant Majors!

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: But that’s how casting people see you, isn’t it, love? Authority figures. Judith starts ‘walking’ the doll up Bill’s leg.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: (singing) “My Grandfather’s a funny ‘un...”

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Don’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: “,..he’s got a face like a pickled onion - “

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Stop it. She gives up. Bill sinks his whisky. Bernard Bresslaw appears on the TV screen, doing his famo catchphrase - “I only arsked". Bill glowers.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bloody rubbish.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Bill! Not in front of Judi. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 Judith starts again.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: “My Grandfather’s a funny ‘un- “”

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I said stop it! Judith reacts as if scalded.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Why are you always so grumpy, Sampa?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What? What’s it got to do with you? Ridiculous child. Judith looks up at him, tears springing to her eyes. Then flees up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: (calling) Judi-poodi! (to Bill) For Heaven’s sake! Go after her, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I told the girl once. What’s wrong with her? Cloth-ears? Heather sighs, gets up and heads for the stairs. She nods the TV.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Don’t you like being successful? He jabs his finger towards the TV.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: That’s not success. I’m legitimate! A legitimate character actor! Of the stage and film! Heather nods wearily. She’s heard all this before.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: (sotto) I only asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mid-June 1963. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: 20A
dialogues.text: al 22 A black cab draws up and VERITY gets out. She’s supremely elegant in a simple black dress and heels. She smooths do her dress and looks up at the impressive new building. We here goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERITY sweeps through TVC, happy, confident and beaming. Heads can’t help but turn.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More heads turn as VERITY passes an open door. Somebody giggles. Verity stops, turns. The giggler is shushed. Discomfited, looks back. Two people have stepped out into corridor and are watching her. We only see them as silhouettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERITY throws open an office door to find REX and MERVYN huddled over a desk, ploughing through 10 x 8 photos of actors. There are lots more photos on the walls. The two don’t look up as Verity arrives.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: What about Leslie French? He’d be marvellous.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: He’s working with Visconti. Gave us a polite ‘no’.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: Cyril Cusack?

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: A less polite ‘no’. (looks up, sees Verity) Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: I think you’re in my office.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: That's a rather interesting way of looking at it. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: I'm rather an interesting person.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: (puzzled) I don’t doubt it. Rex Tucker. I’m looking after ‘Doctor Who’.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Pending the appointment of the permanent producer.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: (peering behind her) Oh. Is he with you?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: You're looking at him. Rex ignores her and goes back to the photos.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: I keep coming back to Hugh David.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: (mollifying) He was in ‘Knight Errant’ on ITV. Lovely actor.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Not old enough for the Doctor, surely?

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: (sharp) Well, we don’t want Grandpa Moses, do we? We need someone who can play older. The shooting schedule’s going to be pretty punishing.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: I’ve got some ideas.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: I‘1l call Hugh. See what he thinks.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: I'd rather you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: Is that a fact?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Waste of time. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL  23 An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/13 There’s a frosty silence.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We need someone like Frank Morgan in the Wizard of Oz.

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: (grumpy ) He’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Rex -

dialogues.speaker: REX
dialogues.text: And American.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: I said “like”. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Well, perhaps we should all sleep on it. After all, it took them months to find Scarlet O'Hara! No-one laughs. Verity gathers her things. Mervyn takes Verity’s elbow.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Um... dear lady, may I have a word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An almost empty studio. Unmanned cameras stand by like robots. There’s also a primitive autocue machine. MERVYN is holding a script. He prepares his pipe. VERITY stands opposite, flinty and unsmiling.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: You were Sydney’s production assistant on the other channel?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: So this is quite a promotion.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Apparently. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Bound to ruffle a few feathers.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: If feathers don’t ruffle, nothing flies. Mervyn smiles. Very good.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: This show is going to be a terrific challenge, you know. Outer space. Time Travel. He holds up the script: An Unearthly Child’ by Anthony Coburn.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In the first script they go back to the Stone Age. You’ll need all the help you can get. So Rex is to act as a... mentor to you.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: (shakes head) A ship can’t have two captains.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Dear lady -

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Please don’t call me that.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: And what about you? What’s your function?

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: I’m to be your sort of technical boffin. Help you through the mire of all this. He gestures at the equipment.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: (sighs) Sydney obviously thinks I’m the right person for the job. That’s what he wants for ‘Doctor Who’. Someone with piss and vinegar in their veins.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Is that what he said? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: He’s very blunt.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Ye-es. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, all I’m saying dear (lady) - Verity gives him a sharp look.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Verity. All I'm saying is that experience is not a dirty word. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t fight us. Perhaps you could add a few drops of warm beer in with your...

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Piss and -

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: (over) Mixture. Just for the time being. Verity just shrugs. That’s the best he’s going to get for now.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (checks watch) Well. We'd better clear out. The News people will be arriving. Verity taps the autocue machine.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: That’s clever. So they don’t have to look down at their words all the time.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Yes. Quite a wheeze.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Someone’1ll make a fortune out of that.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: I suppose so. Shame I didn’t get to the patent office faster. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL  24 25 An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/13

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: I invented it. He ambles out of the studio. On Verity: Oh. Over this: a phone ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: July 1963. HEATHER picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Hello? Oh, hello, love. (listens) Oh yes? She smiles with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL and HEATHER are out walking the dog in the muddy fie near the cottage.

dialogues.text: Well, have a look, Bill. It certainly sounds different. It’s an old man part, you know.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (excited) Is it?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yes! Like ‘This Sporting Life’.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I love playing older!

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Well? When’s he sending it? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Popped it in the post today. He sounded very upbeat on the phone. Says it’s a smashing role.

dialogues.text: July 1963 - a few days later. A small, dark-haired figure (WARIS HUSSEIN) walks along t corridor, head buried in a script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERITY and MERVYN are looking down from the office window REX is getting into his car. He glances up at them, then drives away. Mervyn pushes his glasses up onto the bridge of his nose.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Am I next? Verity smiles and pats his arm affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Anything from the design department?

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: No. They're not being very helpful, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What is this?! Suddenly, a handsome young Indian man, WARIS appears in t office, waving a script. WARIS (CONT’D) What’re we going to do with this? Stone Age Man going ‘Ug’! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 WARIS (CONT’D) It’s crazy! Cavemen and doctors and disappearing bloody police boxes! (despairs) What’re we going to do? He sinks down into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: (gestures to Waris) Waris Hussein. Our director.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Verity. She holds out her hand. Waris shakes it absently. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What have you just been working on?

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (a bit sheepish) ‘Compact’.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Oh. High art indeed.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (smiles) Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: Don’t people say ‘Ug’ in ‘Compact’?

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Frequently. Mostly after a liquid lunch.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: The Cave Men script is the only one ready to go. So we have to start with it.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: And where are we shooting?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Lime Grove. (grim) Studio ‘D’.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Oh, God, not there! We can’t do anything there! It’s a broom cupboard! It’s smaller on the inside! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: WARIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the wrong shape and the sprinklers go off when it gets hot!

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: (drily) But apart from that...?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Well. You’1l make it brilliantly, won’t you?

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Oh. I see. Simple as that. He sighs and throws the script down. WARIS (CONT’D) It’ll never work. Beat. WARIS (CONT’D) (grins) When do we start?

dialogues.text: INT. BBC CLUB. NIGHT 7 - (19:21 a7 A busy bar. The room is stuffed with middle-aged white me haze of tobacco smoke hanging over them. WARIS is waiting be served. VERITY sits at a nearby table. The Barman turns and Waris tries to get served.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Excuse me — The Barman glances at him - then pointedly serves someone else first.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: Yes sir?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Vodka and tonic and a red wine, please. Waris looks up. Verity’s now next to him.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: Sorry, love, I’m serving - Verity gives him a terrifying glare.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Vodka and tonic and a red wine. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 He opens his mouth to argue - but then decides against it lifts a glass to the vodka optic.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Thanks. I’d have been stood here all night. He looks away and catches sight of a very dishy YOUNG MAN the corner of the bar, giving him the glad eye. Waris looks away, hugely embarrassed. Verity has noticed. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: “We are all strangers in a_ strange land.”

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Very profound.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Isn‘’t it? (smiles) You'll find I’m generally pretty profound.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: I wish I had your front.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: I wish I had your behind.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Shh!

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Like a little peach.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (laughing) Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Don’t be fooled, love. That’s all it is. Front. Inside, I’m shaking like a leaf.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (nods ) I'm here by the skin of my bloody teeth too. First Indian director this place has ever had! Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: So, we've got to stick together, haven't we? Make our little show work. That’1l teach them.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: The old guard. (looks about) This sea of fag smoke, tweed and sweaty men.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not that I’m knocking sweaty men.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (grins) I should hope not. He risks another look. The Young Man is still there. He smiles. Waris looks away again. Beat. WARIS (CONT’D) Listen, I don’t know how to say this... I overheard a couple of old horrors standing by the tea urn. They said “Well, she didn’t get here standing up, did she?”

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Ha! Sydney’s bit of fluff, am I?

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: That seems to be the impression. How else could you get a promotion like this?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: A promotion like what? I'm trying to re-create the Stone Age with Airfix glue and bloody bacofoil!

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: We’re trying to.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Yes. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: It doesn’t bother you? That they talk? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: It’s change, Waris. That’s what they can’t stand. Change. Anyway, I’ve got a plan.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: I’m going to treat myself. Every week. New dress. New earrings. Then, when I hear them whispering, I‘1l tell myself it’s just about my fabulous new wardrobe! Waris glances across the room again. The Young Man linger for a moment on the threshold of the bar, then makes a sa face and goes. Verity clocks this but doesn’t say anythin Waris raises his vodka.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Here’s to us. The posh wog!

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: And the pushy Jewish bird!

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: L'chaim!

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: We could have our own series!

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: We do! They drink.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: So. What about our lead? Anyone in mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mid-July 1963 - a few days later.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I don’t want any of this muck, thanks very much. I’1l have a drink. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 BILL sits in between VERITY and WARIS at a round table in Chinese restaurant. He looks sour and more than a little uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Right. Waris looks round for a waiter.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You're the director, son?

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Yes! Bill looks him up and down, then glances at Verity.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Hardly out of the cradle, the pair of you. (sighs) Right. Let’s talk turkey. I’m not sure about this. Not sure at all.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No. Apart from anything else, I don’t want to take on another long run. Had enough of that on ‘The Army Game’. Nearly killed me. Like weekly bloody rep! The waiter approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whisky and soda. Chopee, chopee. Waris winces a little.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whose idea was all this? That fella from ITV?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Sydney Newman, yes. But so many people have been in at the birth of the thing... (shrugs ) We'd be here all day... Under this: Dum-de-dum-dum-de-dum.. Hesitant notes on a piano...

dialogues.speaker: WARIS

dialogues.speaker: BILL

dialogues.text: (shakes head) No. Too corny.

dialogues.text: We see a wooden door being screwed into place on its hing

dialogues.text: No, it adapts to suit its environment.

dialogues.text: Pricey. Changing what it looks like every week.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A police box?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY

dialogues.text: And the opening titles are like nothing you’ve ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: DELIA
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Most of it.

dialogues.text: And what about the Doctor himself?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Your character? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL  42 An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/13

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (warming) We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: He whisks the school teachers off from their own time. But he can’t remember how to fly his ship. So they're always landing in unexpected places. He’s something like six hundred years old. Looks like a senile old man but he’s tough.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Tough and wiry like an old turkey. It’s what you do so well, Mr Hartnell. Stern and scary - Bill gives him a look. WARIS (CONT’D) - but with a twinkle.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Trust me, Bill. You’re perfect for it. No-one will be able to resist you.

dialogues.speaker: BILL

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: C.S. Lewis meets H.G. Wells meets Father Christmas! That’s the Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: BILL

dialogues.text: You're a brick for doing this.

dialogues.text: Contractually obliged, darling -

dialogues.speaker: VERITY

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (to Russ, nodding towards Bill) What do you make of him?

dialogues.speaker: RUSS
dialogues.text: Oh, I’ve always been a fan. Wonderful screen actor.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He frightens the life out of me.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: I think he’s sweet. Bless him.

dialogues.speaker: RUSS

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Must’ve had a tough life. (to Carole) You ok?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: Scared to death!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Me too. Beat.

dialogues.text: Oh well. Goodbye real world! Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 42aA

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Patience.

dialogues.speaker: BILL

dialogues.text: Bugger. “If you could touch the alien sand and hear the cry of strange birds and watch them wheel in another sky, would that satisfy you? Susan and I are cut off from our own people. dialogues.text: My granddaughter.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Do you know how to fly a time machine, Sampa?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Hm? Yes! Yes, of course I do! You’1l see. You’1ll see when I’m on the television. We'll be going back through history to meet Kings and Queens. And off to distant planets where the Doctor will have all kinds of adventures.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: The Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: That’s the old man I’m playing.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH

dialogues.text: August 1963 - a few days later. A junkyard set with big wooden gates. Amidst the broken furniture, shop dummies etc is the police box exterior of TARDIS. In their everyday clothes are BILL, RUSS and JACK scripts in hand. WARIS is seated by the wall, watching intently. CAROLE si by him. dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Don’t you think you’re being rather high-handed, young man? You thought you saw a young girl enter the yard. You imagine you heard her voice? Not very substantial is it? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: But why won’t you help us? VERITY comes over.

dialogues.text: (sotto) How is he?

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (sotto) Tetchy as hell.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’m not hindering you. If you both want to make fools of yourselves, I suggest you do what you said you’d do and ask a policeman... bugger - find a policeman.

dialogues.speaker: RUSS

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (sotto) Nice frock.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: (sotto) Thank you. (smiles) Everyone's talking about it. Waris nods to Carole.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: (calls) What are you doing out there?

dialogues.speaker: RUSS
dialogues.text: She is in there!

dialogues.speaker: BILL

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Ok! Ok, everyone. That’s where we stop the tape and go inside the spaceship.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: If it’s ever built! Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL  45 46 An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/13

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Yes. Ok. Good. Well done. Everyone happy?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No, I’m not happy. Not at all! Miss Lambert! A word, if you please!

dialogues.speaker: RUSS
dialogues.text: (quickly) Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: Good idea! Good idea! They melt away to the tea urn where ARTHUR, a cameraman s reading his paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYDNEY marches purposefully down the corridor. STAFF get of his way as he powers along.

dialogues.text: INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. DAY 11 - (15:38) 46 BILL is with VERITY. WARIS stays to one side, seemingly checking props but trying to keep out of it.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: The set for the machine? TARDIS? When is it arriving?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: There’s been a... delay.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: It won’t do. It just won’t do!

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry -—

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I don’t know how I’m expected to... to cope with all the gibberish I have to spout without a bloody set to work on. I need time to plot out all the buttons, you see.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Buttons? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: On the controls! All the switches and dials. I need to know what they all do, don’t I? What if I press something to close the doors and the next week I use it to blow us all up! You must see that? The children will spot it, you see, if we try and fudge it. Waris and Verity exchange a look. Verity looks a bit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYDNEY approaches the entrance to the studio.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 46B INT. LIME GROVE STUDIO ‘D’. DAY 11 - (15:41) 46B

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (waves script) And we must discuss my character!

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Right -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: He’s too abrasive. Too nasty. Do you see? Where’s that twinkle you talked about? The thing that made me so right for it? Verity spots SYDNEY striding into the studio and grabs hi arm.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Sydney Newman, Head of Drama - may I introduce Mr William Hartnell -

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Right! Our Doctor! Great choice. I'm a big fan. Big fan.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Thank you. But I need to discuss -

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: What was that terrific war picture, you did? What was that? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Well, I’ve done a few. ‘The Way Ahead’?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah! Hell of a picture. You were sensational!

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Oh. Do you really think so?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: (joining in) Oh yes. Absolutely extraordinary.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I did get some very nice notices. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (chiming in) Was that before or after ‘Brighton Rock’?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Um. Before...

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Of course! You were in ‘Brighton Rock’! Wow! Wonderful performance.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Oh. Well. Haha. You’re very kind. (shrugs ) It should have led to much bigger and better things, you know but... I wasn’t blessed.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Not blessed? What the hell are you talking about? Sure you’re blessed. You're going to be Doctor Who, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Well, yes -

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Perfect choice for my little show. My idea anyway. That’s what I do. Ideas! I came into ITV one day. I got an idea, I said. ‘The Avengers’! What’s it about, they said. How the hell should I know, I said. But what a title! (mimes machine gun) Pop! Pop! Pop! Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 He roars with laughter. Bill can’t help but be charmed.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going to make a huge impact with this character, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Only a movie star could do it. So nuanced. So many layers. Bill flutters a little. Of course, he’s delighted.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Well, you know. One tries. Sydney brings Waris into the fold, wrapping his arms roun him and Verity.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: And these kids are perfect for it. Couldn't be in safer hands. Energy! Youth! Fun! Pop! Pop! Pop! He mimes the machine gun again. They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ARTHUR the cameraman looks over from his ‘Daily Mail’ and glares at the motley little group.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (with distaste) Freaks.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: BILL goes off, still chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Thank you so much, Sydney. You’ve no idea what a diff -

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (sharp) Be a producer, Verity! Find a way to deal with this stuff! Or are you out of your depth? He exits. Verity is chastened. She looks over at Waris th gathers herself. Right.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERITY marches determinedly down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERITY plonks herself down into a chair opposite PETER. H desk is strewn with bits and bobs for model making. Glue, balsa wood, paints, cotton reels. He’s smoking and poppin discs out of a piece of pre-formed white plastic.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Being patient.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: I can be very patient.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You can’t stay here! He starts gluing the popped-out discs onto a model chario make wheels.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Now what shall we talk about? I’ve got all day.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Don’t be ridiculous! Verity gestures round the walls at the framed pictures.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: The Old Curiosity Shop! The Roman Forum! The Hanging Gardens of Babylon! Symphonies in pencil and ink. So, surely you can knock me up a teeny little time machine? Peter plonks the cotton reel in the middle of the desk.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just turn that blazing talent to my little kiddies’ show and who knows what might happen? Won’t take you half an hour, will it?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You are a very trying woman - Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL  48 An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/13

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Then I’1l get out of your hair. Peter takes a many-sided thruppeny bit out of his pocket puts it on top of the cotton reel.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe the Muse will be with you! Maybe it’1l be the best thing you ever thought of - Peter rapidly assembles the discarded plastic sheets into three ‘walls’. Without the popped-out ‘discs’ they have distinctive round holes in them.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Very well! Very well! Here! Here, madam! Here’s your bloody ‘TARDIS’! Verity gets up and looks down at the ‘model’. She smiles. We fade from this image to --

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.text: -- the TARDIS interior in all its glory. September 1963. The studio floor. In costume, BILL, RUSS and JACKIE are standing by the Police Box double doors - which are being held in place by two stage hands. Bill and Carole are in slightly odd versions of their costumes. Bill has a regular collar and tie, Carole a mor ‘alien’ outfit. Close on a studio clock. Eight minutes to ten. Four cameras stand close by. Massive, thick cables cover floor like spaghetti.

dialogues.speaker: RUSS
dialogues.text: Turned out rather well, hasn’t it? Jackie nods, thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Through the cupboard doors and into Narnia!

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: It’s too bloody big. Takes up half the studio. What’s the delay, son? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 DOUGLAS, the assistant director walks into shot, listenin his head-set. Next to him, behind a camera is ARTHUR.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Sorry boys and girls. (into head set) He says he won’t have his teeth blacked out, guv.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 49 INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. GALLERY. NIGHT 12 - (21:5

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: But it’s a 100,000 BC!

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: It’s the Tribe of Gum! The studio gallery is tense. It’s been a long day and tim running out. In the director’s chair is WARIS. All eyes a on him.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He says he got them whitened so he could get onto the telly!

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (sighs) Well... does it matter? We only see his bloody shadow -

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 50 INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. NIGHT 12 - (21:54) 50 A hairy caveman - LEN - approaches DOUGLAS.

dialogues.speaker: LEN
dialogues.text: I'll do it!

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LEN
dialogues.text: I don’t mind. Blacking my teeth. I’ve already got sand-fleas in my Y- fronts. Can’t get much worse. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Stout man! (into headset) Think we’re sorted, guv.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 51 INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. GALLERY. NIGHT 12 - (21:5

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Thank you, Duggie. The studio bell rings and a red light comes on.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Roll to record in fifteen... fourteen...

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (rubs his brow) God it’s hot in here. Anyone else hot? Can we do something about the heat?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 5a INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. NIGHT 12 - (21:55) 52

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (sotto) Thought he’d be used to it.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Watch it, Arthur. Arthur checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Five minutes, chum. Then they turn the lights out. Them’s the rules. More burbling from Douglas’s head-set.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: Ok, everyone. Quiet please. QUIET! Five four... three... two... one... Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 He nods to Jackie. She barges through the doors -

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. GALLERY. NIGHT 12 - (21:56) - and, on the gallery monitors, finds herself inside the huge, white room, which hums with power.

dialogues.text: INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’ - TARDIS. NIGHT 12 - (21:56) JACKIE looks round in awe. RUSS tumbles in after her, followed by BILL. CAROLE stands by the six-sided console.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Close the doors, Susan. She flicks a switch and the doors begin to close.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These people are known to you, I believe?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? They’re two of my school-teachers.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Is that your excuse for this unwarrantable - unwarranted - intrusion? Bill tries to take off his scarf but can’t find its end. pats ineffectually about at his shoulders. Dialogue from the scene continues under...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. GALLERY. NIGHT 12 - (21:57) On the monitor, the shot changes. Unfortunately CAROLE is blocking BILL.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (wipes his brow) Move, move, move! The camera tries to shift but it’s no good. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: WARIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Move the bloody camera!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR tries to move his huge, unwieldy camera.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (sotto) Doing my best. I’1l rupture myself. The huge double doors bang shut with a loud report.

dialogues.speaker: RUSS
dialogues.text: Where are we? Then one of the doors swings open again. Then bangs shut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: again.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 57 INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. GALLERY. NIGHT 12 - (21:5

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: The doors! What’s happening to the doors?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 58 INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’ - TARDIS. NIGHT 12 - (22:0

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bangs loudly against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: But you look like us, you sound like us!

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: I was born in the 49th Century! On the other side of the set, DOUGLAS and the stagehands struggling manfully to close the doors.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS
dialogues.text: (sotto) Christ. Stiff as a Scotchman’s wallet.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: I made up the name TARDIS from the initials Time and Relative Dimension in Space. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought you’d understand when you saw the different dimensions inside from those outside. Douglas's shadow creeps hugely across the back of the TAR wall. Then - suddenly - rain! Carole shrieks. The studio sprinklers go off, soaking everyone. Then all the lights go out! Dimly, the outline of Len the caveman.

dialogues.speaker: LEN
dialogues.text: Am I on yet?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. GALLERY. NIGHT 12 - (22:01) Waris lays his head on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Wish I knew what bloody dimension I was in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late September 1963 - a few days later. SYDNEY is marching down a corridor, behind him are VERITY WARIS. STAFF look round, as usual.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. DAY 13 - (12:40) 61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deserted studio. We pass through the junkyard set as dialogue form the episode reverberates around. As we snake through the empty TARDIS set we hear:

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s out of the question. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL  62 An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/13 Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I won’t go, Grandfather. I won’t leave the 20th Century. I’d rather leave the TARDIS and you.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now you’re being sentimental and childish.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, I mean it!

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Very well. Then you must go with them. I’ll open the doors.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Are you coming, Susan? The TARDIS engines grind into life...

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh no, Grandfather! No!

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Let me go! Get back to the ship, child!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. GALLERY. DAY 13 - (12:41) 68

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On screen WARIS and anxiously in the darkened gallery, the finished episode. VERITY - in another striking new dress - are watching. On the monitor: the incongruous sight of the TARDIS, in splendid isolation on a frozen, prehistoric plain. The sh of LEN falls across it... The theme music pounds out and the credits roll. In the dim light, cigarette smoke blossoms. SYDNEY is sit at the back of the gallery. The lights come up. Waris and Verity look round. Sydney doesn’t smile.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Let’s go to lunch.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYDNEY tucks into his food.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Not eating?

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: Don’t seem to have much of an appetite.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Not surprised. I should fire the pair of you. Verity’s eyes blaze a little. Sydney looks down at his notes.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take out the reference to the future time they’ve come from. The 49th Century? Too specific. This is ‘Dr Who’, remember. Old guy’s too nasty. He should be cuter. Funnier. The kid should be more cheeky too. Like a regular teenager. And that scene inside the time machine... He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: (sighs) Maybe I will have something. Hemlock?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Did you like any of it?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Not much. Hate the opening titles.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: You're joking?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Too weird. And the music’s awful.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: It’s sensational! Just because it’s new.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (sharp) Hey, I like new, remember? New is what I do! But it’s too scary for the kids. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: WARIS
dialogues.text: I thought we were trying to scare them.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Scare them, not traumatise them! Change it.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Over my dead body.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: It can be arranged! Frosty silence. Sydney sighs and rubs his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’ll cost. And they’1l crucify me for it but... Waris and Verity look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: What? Sydney wipes his mouth with a napkin and rises.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Do the whole thing again!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. LIME GROVE. STUDIO ‘D’. DAY 14 - (14:20) 64 Late September 1963 - a day later. CLOSE on BILL.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (groans) It’s because of me, isn’t it? BILL sits with VERITY by the Police Box on the junkyard s

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: No -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I knew it. I sensed it!

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: No, no, Bill. Not at all! Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I should stick to what I know. I’m not right for the part -

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Bill -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Just not right for it. It isn’t me. Isn’t me at all! Verity takes his hands and squeezes them.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Bill! Listen to me. Sydney thought it was good! He’s... he’s over the moon! But I’ve let you down.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Let me down?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: You were right. You were so right. We’ve made the Doctor too abrasive. We need much more of you in him. Much more charm and warmth and... twinkle. You knew it - and I didn’t see it.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: And you’re sure you’ve got the right man?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Of course I am.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I'm frightened, you see, love. Never done anything like this before. The pressure of it. And the schedule, all those ruddy words...

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: I’m here for you, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Every step. Bill squeezes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to tell the others now.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Time and tide wait for no man, eh? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL  65 66 67 An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/13

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Time and space, Bill. And they wait for no woman, either! Verity reaches the studio door and throws it open. RUSS, CAROLE and JACKIE are all seated there, like patients ina waiting room. They all look up as Verity appears. She tak deep breath and beams.

CAROLE’s too when we see it - a trendy Carn Street top.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’m not hindering you. If you both want to make fools of yourselves, I suggest you do what you said you’d do, go and find a policeman.

dialogues.speaker: RUSS
dialogues.text: While you nip off quietly in the other direction?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Insulting. There’s only one way in and out of this yard. I want to see your faces when you try and explain away your behaviour to a policeman, Chesserman - er Chesterton.

dialogues.text: VERITY looks out over London, pensive. Over this:

dialogues.speaker: DONALD, (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: DONALD

dialogues.text: Aha.

dialogues.text: Ratings too. Respectable. Considering what happened.

dialogues.text: Mm. MERVYN walks in.

dialogues.text: Sydney wants to see you, Verity.

dialogues.text: INT. SYDNEY’S OFFICE. DAY 19 - (10:49) 82 VERITY’s fist banging on SYDNEY’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: We have not over-spent!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: The figures speak for themselves. It’s my fault. I promoted you too soon.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Verity, there’s no getting past it. You're way over budget. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.text: No! Sydney, when you asked me to produce this show you made it abundantly clear that you wanted it to run all year round. Right?

dialogues.text: The TARDIS is an expensive set. Of course it is. And it was budgeted accordingly.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: No - over forty eight. That was the deal!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You sure you’ve got your numbers right?

dialogues.text: (temper rising) Look, am I the bloody producer or not? If you want to do it all your way, Sydney - fine. I’1l walk away and you never need to hear from me again -

dialogues.text: Even if I can sort out this TARDIS mess, I don’t much like the way the show's going. First Goddamned cavemen -—

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Now these... (gestures helplessly) ...Dayleks.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY

dialogues.text: They’re exactly what I wanted to avoid! Cheapjack science fiction trash.

dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.text: Enough to know garbage when I see it! Jesus. “Darloks"”.

dialogues.text: Daleks.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Whatever! Bug-eyed -

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: (yelling) They’re not bug-eyed monsters! Sydney is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (with increasing passion) They used to be like us. Radiation has made them retreat inside these impregnable metal shells and now they hate everything that isn’t like them. All they know how to do is lash out. The Doctor and his friends turn up and try to make them see differently. To understand other people and make peace. It’s strong stuff. dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Well, I wanted someone with piss and vinegar.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: You got them! I think we have something very special here, Sydney. A knockout. We’ve just got to hold our nerve. Beat.

dialogues.text: Spread the cost of the time machine... Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.text: Off-set it against less expensive episodes... A look from Verity. Obviously.

dialogues.text: Ok. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ok. I’1l talk to the high-ups. He dismisses Verity with a curt nod. Verity marches to th door but, on the threshold, turns back.

dialogues.text: (off Verity’s look) Hardening of the arteries.

dialogues.text: But if there’s anything you can do to... take some of the burden off his shoulders. Let him slow down a little.

dialogues.text: Well, I’1l have a quiet word with my successor.

dialogues.text: Your...? Oh. (face falls) Oh. They both look over at Bill. He waves cheerily.

dialogues.text: Vortis? What galaxy is that in? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 114

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: The Isop Galaxy, Chesterfield. Chesterton! Many, many light earths... (he struggles) .--light years...from us. From Earth. And yet the Vortis...Vortis Planet hasn’t a moon. Hmm? Eh? Russ looks blank.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Hold it there, please!

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Sorry. I’m so sorry, Russ. I gave you the wrong line...

dialogues.speaker: RUSS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL mops his forehead with his hankie. He’s with VERITY. gestures at his script.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I can do all this with a look, you see, my dear. I don’t need all these lines. Like ruddy ‘King Lear’! I remember Lindsay Anderson saying the same thing about me on ‘Sporting Life’. He just ripped a couple of pages out of the script. ‘Bill can do this with a gesture’, he said. ‘A raised eyebrow’. Do you see what I mean?

dialogues.text: Of course. She glances at Richard who’s schooling the Menoptera in their insect mannerisms. He shrugs exasperatedly.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Bless you. He puts his arm around her. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.text: Actually, I’m glad to have the chance to speak to you, Bill -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You're my rock, Verity. You know that. My rock.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Since that day you first started telling me about ‘Doctor Who’. I’ve been spellbound. Spellbound! And look at us now, eh? Just look at us! Verity smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: ..»-which was her way of saying - take a hike! He beams at his protégée.

dialogues.text: - to Verity. Best damn appointment I’ve ever made. Applause. The crowd sing ‘For she’s a jolly good fellow’. Verity makes her way through the crowd, being hugged by t assembled. She plants a big kiss on a Dalek’s eye-stalk. looks over the crowd and sees BILL, sloping off.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So... what’s Gerald Harper got that I haven't, hmm?

dialogues.text: (laughs ) Oh he’s not a patch on you! But it’s a lovely idea, Bill. I’m very excited about it. ‘Adam Adamant’. He’s an Edwardian gentleman frozen in time. A relic. He doesn’t fit in with the modern world and... She tails off. Sounds a bit too close for comfort.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «--and -

dialogues.text: Bill. I wanted to say thank you. For everything you've done. I’m in demand! And it’s all it’s down to you -

dialogues.text: Oh nonsense.

dialogues.text: But why does it have to change? Why do things always have to change? Why can’t we just all go on as we are?

dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Life. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VERITY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What about you? Not ready for a rest?

dialogues.text: Me? Not at all. Not a bit! This old body of mine is good for a few years yet! When you gave me the chance to do this, Verity, I grabbed it with both hands. His hands go automatically to his lapels.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Oh, you've got...

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Let me. He takes a clean, pressed hankie from his jacket pocket a gently rubs the red wine stain from Verity’s lips.

dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry -

dialogues.text: (sighs) Ok. Top of the scene, then.

dialogues.text: Right. Yes. Sorry. Bill takes his place by the TARDIS console. Nothing happe

dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sorry. Be right with you. Bill sighs. Wipes his brow. He can hear voices off set. H looks round, distracted.

dialogues.speaker: BILL

dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr Hartnell. A very young stagehand comes on and tries to make the tim rotor move.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Careful with that.

He starts the scen Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 120 121

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now they’ve all gone. All gone. None of them could understand. Not even my little Susan. Or Vicki. And there’s Barbara and Chatterton - Chesterton!

dialogues.text: (sotto) Oh, God...

dialogues.text: (thrown ) Perhaps I should go back to my own time. Back to my own planet. But I... Bill stops dead. Just stares at the camera. Beat. Beat. He puts his hand to his eyes and shuffles off the set.

dialogues.text: June 1966 - a few weeks later. SYDNEY is presiding over a meeting. With him is MERVYN. Sydney’s going through a sheaf of memos.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: As you can see —

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: It can’t go on. He’s become so difficult to work with. And his lines... He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I hear you!

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN
dialogues.text: (gentler) Poor chap’s worn out.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Shame. Goddam shame.

dialogues.speaker: MERVYN

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (looks up) What do you mean?

dialogues.text: A light knock at the door. It’s the First AD - DOUGLAS.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr Hartnell, sir? They’re asking for you. No response.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Shall I tell them you’re coming now?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Tell them what you like.

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Beg pardon, Mr Hartnell?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Tell them what you bloody well like!

dialogues.speaker: DOUGLAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Listen, I’m only doing my job -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (shouts ) Sod off will you? I’m not ready. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need more time. Douglas sighs and goes away. Bill glances over at his famous costume, hanging off the of the door. With difficulty, he slumps into a chair -

dialogues.text: - opposite his own TV. BILL is washed out. Totally draine He cradles a whisky. JUDITH comes trotting happily down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Sampa! Sampa!

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (weary) Oh. Hello there. She runs up and kisses him. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 On Bill:

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Where are you going to take the TARDIS next, Sampa?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (gently) Oh I don’t know, love -

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Miss says you should go back in time and see Oliver Cromwell and tell him not to be so horrible.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Yes, maybe I should.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: But I want the butterfly men to come back! They were pretty. We did them at school and I was a Zarbi.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Listen, Judi -

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: They could have a big fight with the Daleks and you could fly on their backs with a bow and arrow -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Listen, darling. You mustn’t expect too much of your old grandfather, you know. I get very tired these days and -

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Graham Potter says the TARDIS will run out of petrol soon -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: - I need to take things a bit easier.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: But I told him he was stupid. The TARDIS will go on and on forever because it’s special and magic. Like my Sampa.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: My Sampa’s Doctor Who. And he can do anything. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 A glimmer of renewed energy. And something else. Hope.

dialogues.text: July 1966 - a few days later. Outside Sydney’s office.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I hope you don’t think it presumptuous of me to ask for this meeting, Sydney...

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Presumptuous? Hell, no Bill. I... I was going to ask you to come in, as it happens.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Oh yes?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Things... can’t go on the way they are.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Exactly, Sydney! Exactly! You see, I’m committed to ‘Doctor Who’. Hundred percent committed. But I need more time off. The bloody schedule would kill a man half my age.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Aha.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: And all those lines they give me! The kiddies don’t want to hear all that waffle. Perhaps it would be best if the writers just... well sort of sketched in the story and left me to make up the rest? Sydney reacts. Bill picks up on it.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. That’s probably a step too far. But you take my meaning? I’m the star of the show. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 BILL (CONT’D) I’m the Doctor. And if we’re to continue, you need to take account of that. Proper account. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: We've got great plans for ‘Doctor Who’, Bill, believe you me. Great plans. We’re hundred percent committed too.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’m very glad to hear it!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: But we’re looking at ways of... refreshing it. Um... Regenerating it.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Hm. Yes. Quite right. Spice things up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Bill -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’m glad we’re on the same wavelength anyway!

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Bill... hell, there’s no easy way of saying this... We want ‘Doctor Who’ to go on.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: But not with you. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like you said. Things have got to change. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I see. Bill nods. He knew this was coming. He looks almost relieved. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A new face?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Who... who have you got in mind?

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You're a hard act to follow, Bill -

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No need for the soft-soap, Sydney. You know me better. Who? Slowly, Sydney takes out a photo from a thick file and sl it across the desk. It’s of a saturnine, much younger man with dark hair - PAT.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: You approve?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Quite. Patrick Troughton! Excellent choice. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, Bill. Bill waves a dismissive hand.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: “Fortune, good night, smile once more; turn thy wheel!”

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: ‘Lear’. I did it once. Carried a spear. Long time ago. He stares into space.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Long, long time ago. He gives a mirthless chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I said right at the start, if we're lucky, ‘Doctor Who’ could run five years, didn’t I? Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 125 126

dialogues.speaker: SYDNEY
dialogues.text: (kindly) Yeah. You sure did. Who knows? Maybe even longer.

dialogues.text: I think it’s for the best, Bill. Truly I do. You can’t go on like this.

dialogues.text: (nods ) And I’ve made my mark. Showed everyone I could do it. I’m sure it’ll lead to lots more interesting stuff, eh? Heather nods. But she doesn’t look him in the eye. Copyright BBC PRIVATE AND CONFIDENTIAL An Adventure in Space & Time - SHOOTING SCRIPT - 01/02/1 127

dialogues.text: Yes. She goes into the kitchen. Bill turns back to the firepla Suddenly, his eyes are wet with tears. He manages to stif sob - but Heather hears and comes dashing back in.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
